awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unmanned Aerial Systems and Specialized Workforce Development to Support Oklahoman Agriculture and Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
Several Oklahoma industries, involved in agriculture, energy generation, as well as oil and natural gas processing/distribution, have recently started employing unmanned aerial systems (UAS or more commonly "drones") to improve the quality of services and reduce operational costs. This project will create a new experiential-learning educational program at the Rose State College (RSC) to train students, who will become the future workforce in the design, maintenance, and use of UAS across a wide range of civilian and military applications. Training this specialized workforce to meet the industry needs presents unique challenges, which cannot be addressed by merely considering UAS as smaller aircraft. One of the points of strength of this UAS program is that it will provide RSC students with a solid background that will allow them to meet the rapidly changing needs of drone technologies. Working in close collaboration with the University of Oklahoma (OU), RSC will establish a pipeline of students from high school to local industries in order to better prepare its graduates for future college experiences. RSC is located in Midwest City, Central Oklahoma, with an under-represented and minority (URM) population exceeding 37%. This ATE project will enhance development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.

The UAS curriculum will be supported by an evidence-based approach in the use of an elaborate evaluation plan that will help to refine and infuse meaningful activities into a technical curriculum. More specifically, this UAS education program for technicians and engineers will provide technical background in the fundamentals of programming, aerodynamics, flight dynamics and control, UAS operations, payloads and applications, materials and manufacturing, as well as UAS regulations. Core math and physics classes will be accompanied by an experiential-learning approach to provide students with extensive hands-on experiences building on the theoretical foundations. Two sophomore-year classes, which are entirely experiential-learning, will also be developed. An additional direct contribution of the proposed activities will be the development of techniques that will make mathematical and complex notions accessible to a diverse set of students.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This joint project between Rose State College (RSC) and the University of Oklahoma (OU) had the following major goals.

1. Train a future workforce in the design, maintenance, and use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV, or as they are more commonly known, drones).

2. Strengthen the matriculation of RSC Engineering and Technology students into the Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering School at OU.

3. Increase UAV and STEM awareness in middle and high school students

Training a future workforce was achieved through a three-pronged approach consisting of: personnel (1a), equipment (1b), and curriculum (1c).

1a) In anticipation of growth in the Engineering and Technology programs, personnel investments and expansions were made. For example, an additional full-time faculty member was hired. Additionally, RSC personnel became trained and more knowledgeable of UAVs, and the instructors teaching courses became Part 107 licensed drone pilots. Finally, RSC students were hired on a part time basis to support the project by maintaining drones, equipment, and assisting with documentation and project website.

1b) Equipment was obtained to support this effort. A variety of drones were purchased to provide students with hands on experience in the operation and maintenance of UAV. Also, modern additive manufacturing equipment (AM) was purchased to assist in students' ability to design, create, and maintain UAVs.

1c) Finally, UAV based curriculum was developed and delivered. Drone based experiential learning modules were developed for the majority of Engineering and Technology courses (including but not limited to: Intro to Engineering, Graphics and Design, Fluid Mechanics, Dynamics, Materials Design and Manufacturing Processes, Introduction to Electronics, and Statistical Quality Control). Design projects were created where students create solutions to modify and maintain UAV. Often AM was used to generate components as part of these projects. Drone based laboratory exercises were developed and implemented for both Physics I and II courses. Some of these laboratories utilized AM generated components which were designed and created by students in other courses. A seminar style Math course titled Mathematics of Drones was created and offered. Finally, a non-credit Drone Mapping course has been developed where students learn to use drones and photogrammetry to generate 2D and 3D models of land, buildings, and structures. This curriculum will evolve into a credit course in the Aviation program at RSC, AVI 1313, focusing on Part 107 preparation and UAV mapping and photogrammetry. This Aviation course will be available for use as a science elective for both the Engineering and Technology programs. As a direct result of this program a total of 392 RSC students received UAV based curriculum!

Strengthening the matriculation between RSC and OU was achieved through consistent collaboration throughout this project, and the culmination occurred in the spring of 2022 when a "2 Plus 2" agreement was signed between the institutions. This agreement provides a formalized pathway for students to take 2 years of courses at RSC and 2 years of courses at OU to meet all of the requirements for a BS in Mechanical Engineering.

Efforts to increase UAV and STEM awareness in middle and high school students were largely achieved through events on RSC campus and visits to local schools. UAVs were used as a tool to demonstrate physics principles such as lift and drag, and technology principles were demonstrated through the electronics, motors, and control systems associated with UAVs. Additionally, students were exposed to the AM equipment acquired through this effort, and as a result they became aware of the impact AM will have on the aerospace industry's future. Whenever possible, students were allowed to fly drones to provide a hands-on opportunity and spark inspiration to pursue STEM studies in the future. By competition of the project, 227 middle and high school students were exposed to UAV and STEM applications as a result of this effort!

This project had a major impact on RSC and central Oklahoma in terms of increasing UAV and STEM capabilities and awareness, and the results of this effort will have lasting effects. The faculty at RSC have developed substantial expertise in UAV's, AM, and the aerospace industry. A much stronger partnership now exists between OU and RSC, and finally a variety of students, recent graduates, and future STEM professionals have a much better understanding of UAVs and their practical applications in STEM as a result of this program.

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2022
Modified by: Steven Fowler
